transcript.transcript: Dr. Michael Blatchford and Los Angeles, California, July 22nd, 1977. Let us begin if you agree. How did you have Mr. Blandford to join the Federal Theatre? How did that fit into your career? I know that you worked in the Theatre Union and had a lot of other experiences before Federal Theatre, but how did that fit in to your 30s experience? Well, um. Can you remind me the year, uh, where are we now? About 36. About 35. The project is just beginning again in the summer of 35, and probably plays didn't go on until early 36. Yeah. Well, the source of my interest in the federal set apart from as an audience, this is working for sure. Because. Yeah, okay. Because I have one of these, I like that, any rate. Uh. My interest was as a playwright, and of course, I'd seen the plays and so on to be involved with the theater and so many people I knew were involved with the Federal Center. But I guess my, my close interest began when, uh, I did a play, wrote a play with Mike gold called Battle Hymn. Uh, the origin of that. I don't know if I wrote you about the origin of the play. Uh, somewhere in the early summer, maybe 34, 33 or 34. Um, Mike gold, whom I knew gave me a, uh, 50 page sketch of the play about John Brown. And Michael was a marvelous journalist. So my interest in the federal sector was as a playwright with Mike gold, who brought this, this sketch of a play, and Mike gold, who was essentially a journalist and not a creative writer in the sense of fiction or involvement, became he was impatient with it. He didn't he didn't want to spend the time. He was, as you know, a revolutionary columnist for the Daily Worker and a and who had contempt for any kind of art for art's sake or anything of the kind. And he asked whether I would be interested in working on the material. And so I began reading and researching and doing it. And I'm not sure to this day whether he ever read the manuscript before the opening night at the Federal Theater. I'm not sure. Uh, but I'm not certain of that. I have a feeling that he. I don't know, but I have no recollection of his of discussions with him afterwards. And I presented the play on behalf of Mike gold and myself to the Theatre Union, which I was then a director, and I don't remember now on what basis they turned it down, but there was either there was a enough people on the board didn't like it, or they had a schedule that was filled up or one thing or another. And then the Federal Theatre was the, uh, was the outlet. And I guess I gave it to Walter Hart to read. Who gave it to Phil Barber to read, who may have given it to Hallie Flanagan to read. And the next thing I know is that they I was called in or got a telephone call or something saying we'd be interested in doing the play, and we were getting a director. Uh, this may be a great disappointment to you, but that that, uh, my connection with the federal center was not very deep beyond this. Um, I was there during rehearsals and got into several. Uh. Contests with Vincent Sherman, who was directing it. Have you met him? Yes, I yes. I don't know what he's doing now, but I think he's still filming. Mhm. But at that time he was a man of very decided opinions about how to do it. He was a disciple of the, of the Stanislavski method. He was close to the group theater or involved with it, I don't remember. And he had certain very clear, decisive views about how to direct this play. And I had my own views about some of the things. And we got into several arguments for the life of me. I don't remember what they were about, but I do remember they were pretty sharp. Why was John Brown a good, good subject matter? Why did that provide good subject matter for the 30s? If you say so. Mike Gold is thinking about writing a play. What is there about intrinsically about this story that appealed to him, if only initially? Well, you know, it's self-evident that Brown was a revolutionist in his time. Freeing of the slaves going into the South, and also because he was not he was not an abolitionist in the in the conventional sense of the word. He was willing to to, as he said, the sins of this land will not be cleansed except but by blood. That's a sort of a revolutionary circumstance. It had to do with the blacks. It had to do with revolutionary approach to the blacks. At that time, the communists, the Communist Party program probably He included the notion of a of a slogan they had. No one will believe that in the heart of Beverly Hills will they? And you. You just want to keep it on. Of course. Keep it on. Because no one this guy goes through twice a day. And I've been in this office for about 18 years and I was living with this. I love it. I love it. But no one, no one would believe it. Would they? Right. Right under my window in the very heart of Beverly Hills. It's just great. Not a super cheap either. A plain old freight train. No. They keep that franchise on that track going to San Pedro. You see, that's why they have to run the trains twice a day, or else they wouldn't keep their rights to them. The railroad line. But to go back, I think the Communist Party had a slogan then called Self-Determination for the Black Belt. And that idea which derived from early Soviet principles about self-determination for nationalities in Russia. So mechanically, so to speak, they took over into this country that idea of self-determination for the black belt. Um, but of course, it was an absurd idea, but Mike gold might have had that in mind, too, in terms of, uh, in terms of the reflection of what might happen if Brown had been successful. Also, I think what interested gold and what interested me was, uh, the attitude of people like Emerson and Thoreau and others that, so to speak, fellow travelers of the left at that time and, and, uh, their attitudes toward Brown, those who went all the way with him. Those who felt he was too bloody and withdrew from support and so on. It's a. Very interesting scene, isn't. It? Yeah. He meets them. Yeah. And, uh, uh, a lot of material, by the way, I got. And I suspect Mike got, but Mike got, but I'm not sure, uh, from Oswald Garrison Villard, a great biography of John Brown. Uh, there have been others since then, and Brown himself. And at that time in the 30s or, um, uh, left wing writers were looking into our own history for the first time in a long time. Why was that? I'm very interested in that, too, because it's evident from the playscripts that we have. That was was this an attempt to reassess where we'd been in order to go forward? Uh, what was the impulse behind that, would you say? Yeah, the impulse was simple. Uh, here are a bunch of writers. Intellectuals who were involved with the left in the 30s for very good reasons. Anybody who was in his 20s who wasn't involved with the left in the 30s wasn't really thinking, okay, now, uh, but the left had a great the left intellectual, the left creative movement had a great burden to bear. And that is the Russian burden. Uh, Lenin was hero or Gorky was hero, uh, or Trotsky was hero. Uh, but. And the whole Russian and German in the, in the early part of the 30s was the Russian literature and German literature. And the left writers of of Germany is France. Henri Barbusse of France and so on. Now it seems it seems it seemed to us then that we had to find our own roots in our own revolutionary past In literature or history. And so, um, I think writers like Mike gold and many others began to dig and see what there was in our own past, so that the charge that we were simple reflections of a European radicalism would be invalidated because we had our own tradition of radicalism in this country. And names like Crispus Attucks, uh, were revived and, and, uh, and all the, the early revolutionaries, Tom Paine, uh, and Earl Robinson, of course, wrote about the song about Lincoln. At that time. And there were there were there weren't too many. Now you know about the place I'm thinking of novels to or history books. There was a kind of revision, a revision of American literary history, actually. Two men got his name elude me at the moment. Did an American literary history, or completely revising the view of some of the early people? A spiller, Robert Spiller. Right? Yes. Spiller. And the other man whose name I've forgotten. Yeah. Uh, and and a man named Calverton who was nobody remembers who was the editor of the Modern Monthly. And and I was an associate editor then. Uh, did the first what he called sociological, uh, history of American literature, in which he was really was a Marxist version. But he, he, he that was in the late 20s before the depression of the world. No longer this aristocratic hold on. Literature on the past. Right? So there was this revisionist movement, really, which was derived from Marx's view. Mhm. Uh, and so writers began to look back into their own, to our own American tradition to see. And that's where the brown thing and brown was such a perfect example of that, because he was he wasn't an import, he wasn't a refugee. He wasn't an alien. He was a rock of American rock. And did you see him as a religious fanatic in any way, or did you see him more as a, uh, his importance, more as a political figure? Mm. Because, of course, his charge is always made about him. But, uh, again, because he was a man of God. And I saw him as that. I saw him as a religious fanatic. Uh, he couldn't have been very politicalized because he didn't. Absolutely impossible thing. And and I think he was thinking in terms of martyrdom. Uh, and. And it is a marvelous line that came directly from Brown, which I used in the play and which has been used in the biography. And that is when he was accused of killing children. And he said, nits grow up to be lice. Wow. Now you can't, you know, you've got to be a wild man. You've got to be an absolute fanatic to to think that that was a defense for murdering the children of slaveholders. I wanted to go back. And you had mentioned the controversy between you and, uh, Vincent Sherman about how it was put on. Um, if he is coming from the group in Stanislavski direction, are you because of your own predilections and because of your experience with Theater Union coming pretty much from the Meyerhold direction? Would that be a fair thing to say that you're interested in, uh, a different kind of theater or different kind of staging? Uh, because of that interesting? Uh, well, I don't think we would have thought of ourselves as being under Meyerhold's influence. I think we thought of ourselves as the theater union, as people involved with clarity and with, uh, arousing emotion in the audience as directly as possible. Are interested in technique, interested in art, interested in doing it well. But, you know, there's a question of emphasis and. Uh, we directed ourselves to workers. Audiences. No, no. In fact, we had middle class audiences and upper class audiences. They supported us. Nevertheless, when we thought of what kind of impact we wanted in our plays, we thought of the people who paid $0.50 or got free tickets to a union. Workers mostly storm. Uh, actually I ran. I met a very great artist in New York many years ago named de Kooning. And he remembered that that how grateful he was to the Soviet Union because it was the only place he could get in for $0.50, you see. And he himself was, though he was an artist and a painter at that time. He was also a house painter, and he also was a worker, so to speak, in that sense. So, um, um, the group said it was more interested in technique than we were. We were interested in content rather than in technique. And perhaps that was a cause of Sherman Blankfort imbroglio, but I don't really remember. No. And I was just trying to pin it down. It's Brechtian too, obviously, that, uh. Well, Brecht went out of his mind with the Theater Union. I don't know whether you know about that. You know, we did the we did, uh, we did mother, when he hated the way we did it. Did he? Yeah. Yeah. So Scotter presumably liked. Well, But to federal theatre did was life and death in America. What? Uh oh. Have you seen Sklar? Um, I haven't personally, but I probably can. Yes. Yeah. Uh. Piscator liked that. Who directed that? You know, I don't know either. Yeah, but that was done not by the federal union. That was done by the Federal Theatre. No, I was saying that. Oh, really? Are they. Were they so different, the production so different? Or was it perhaps a difference between Brecht and Piscator? Maybe. I'm asking you just to theorize. Yeah, I really don't know. And I think that I think that the differences were. My guess is that ultimately theory comes down to personality and that there were differences between me and and Sherman, which weren't significant. Looking back on it now, but which, you know, build up and go to rehearsal, everything seemed so important. And and the difference is, um, between Brecht and the A steady union they built up. He was a he was a very intense man who was absolutely certain about that. He knew exactly how things were done. And and he didn't like any softening of, of the production or the direction and so on. Acting. How do you see it when we're talking about this? How do you see theater union and federal theater in terms of what audience? To put it sharply, the Federal Theater killed the 30 Union because we couldn't compete. Uh, we the federal said it was federally subsidized. We had to go out and raise money for every production. So the federal said it killed the theater. And that was. And yet and yet none of us, as we were faced with that at board meetings of the Theater Union, none of us felt badly about it. We we had it. And then for about four years, it had been hard work. Everybody had devoted themselves his whole life, really, sort of setting, I mean, and I think it might have petered out after a while anyway, but as far as audience is concerned. Um, I think the audiences were pretty much alike, except that we did more, I think, to reach out for union support than the Federal Theater. They were, uh, and they were reasonable, uh, admission prices. And it was. And then there was a variety of the federal set of children's dead and the dance theater and the music and the the big plays. And it was a marvelous thing. You couldn't keep you couldn't keep up with it. Mhm. And uh. Were they saying, uh, well you, you made the point that they weren't really focusing on workers in the theater union. Were they making those some of the same points that you had hoped to make with the middle class audience or whatever kind of Halloween they And did you have a sense that it was diluted? Well, you know, the federal said it was open to attack as a communist front. From the beginning, I guess, uh, and Hallie Flanagan and I had to fight for support in Congress all the way through. Uh, and I looking back on it, I suspect that many plays that that the Federal Theater did might have been done by the Theater Union. Not many plays, but there were some plays. EP Conklin. He did a play with. Yes. Um. Uh, one on Lincoln called, uh, Prologue to Glory. Prologue to glory. Right. That, I think, was under consideration by the Theater Union. A lot of plays. Not a lot. But there may have been 3 or 4 plays that were under consideration. But for one reason or another, we didn't go ahead with it. Ended up in the Federal theater. So it is possible that the audience was the same. The intent was the same. But when one looked at the federal setup totally, that aspect of reaching out and trying to make a public social statement or even a revolutionary statement was probably pretty well limited to even the living newspaper, which did have a point of view shot point of view. Uh, I mean, we wouldn't look back. We wouldn't. I don't think even Joe McCarthy would have looked at it and thought that it was Communist propaganda. He would have. I don't think he would have. You don't think? No, I don't think he would. I mean, looking back on it. But in those days, um, there was such, uh, sharp political differences that. Uh, I suppose, uh, what we would now seem to take as, uh, let's say the place about blacks play about even an innocent, so to speak, play about blacks in the. If it revealed that they were being discriminated against might have been considered communist propaganda in the 30s. So the federal theatre in many ways did open up the possibilities for other people to talk in a way that might be critical. Yeah, I think so. I think so, yeah, I think so, yeah. It's amazing that in drama there was really until the 20th century, maybe until O'Neill. And that's very mild. No criticism really at the country at all. A social values in the country. Yes. Uh. The first Pulitzer Prize play, 1909, I think, was called Why Marry, uh, by a man named Langdon Mitchell. And the reason I know that marvelous piece of information which no one else would know, would they? Because he was a teacher of mine. Uh, at Penn many years later. But. And I may be wrong. Maybe it's 1999. I'm not sure of the date, but that was what it was when I married. So there were social. There were social comment, but not social political comment. It was all right to make fun of divorce, or make fun of adultery, or make fun of one thing or another in the plays. But. Uh, to take on the American dream. You're right. And O'Neill did. What? Other than his groundbreaking influence would you say the Federal Theater had? What now? Once it was over, um, what difference had it made? Or did it make that it had existed all along, in your opinion? Was there a heritage somehow something that, uh, some way that the theater was changed in a fundamental way? I think it said it was changed through through the individual experience of of creative artists, musicians and directors and writers and so on. Uh. I don't really think it had I mean, let's say that there was a whole aspect of documentary work in film and the theater that derives from the Living newspaper. Mhm. Uh, that that is, I think, a chief contribution stylistically that the Federal Theater made. Uh. In other ways I think perhaps, and you know better than I do about the function and the children's theater. I think maybe they opened something there. But looking at the broad stream of American theater, other than the individuals that came out and not very many did you see, I mean, Arthur Miller didn't come out of the Federal Theater. Odets didn't come out of the federal theatre. Tennessee Williams didn't come out of the theater. Lillian Hellman didn't come out of the Federal theater. Uh, so it's hard to say. I guess it helped. By the way, it's a very interesting question, because to me. Uh, what? Essentially, this is a sort of pessimistic or a downbeat kind of view. What essentially it did was to support creative people for a period of X number of years. And in that effort of supporting them, uh, some creative contribution was made to American culture. For example, the whole marvelous, um, series of of travel books. Um, Who knows what. How many writers or painters and so on. Um, might have died or committed suicide or starved to death or become other things if it hadn't been for the federal center. So in terms of supporting the creative population of this country, the young creative population of this country, I think it was absolutely invaluable. It was just one of the big contributions. But I know it in two, two fields. I know the art field. Many of the great American artists who are living today were worked for the Federal Theatre, and you wouldn't recognize that. See, that was a period in which they were experimenting. That was a period in which they were, uh. The artists the American artists have had to go through. Their own subservience to Picasso or Czanne or Matisse or whatever they. Were going through that. Um, so to speak. Adolescence during the during the federal arts project. They are painting now in a way that is unlike the way they painted then, but it kept them alive. And so I don't think that the federal, state, or the federal arts project at all really influenced the direction of the cultural expression of the nation. But I do think it kept alive those people who really made major contributions to it. Well, that's my notion. And that's not, uh, is it? Is that a common one? I think that so we get two kinds of response, I suppose. people whose careers stopped when the federal Theatre stopped, and people who were able to pick themselves up and take another step and go continue their careers. So we get two kinds of of reactions to the federal idea. But it seems to me that your very interesting point of view and a very hard line point of view, it's not sentimental, and it does tend to sentimentalize sometimes things that everyone's past well, either idealized. What about the National Theater? Is there a chance now for a national theater that maybe, at minimum, could you ever sell a government program on the basis of helping giving artists and writers an opportunity to survive while they find themselves with? In your opinion, is that a viable program today? Are we likely to get anything like that under Carter? Well, I have a general feeling first I am very skeptical of national subsidies for the arts simply because it involves national censorship, and that bothers me. Now, we haven't had it in, let's say, the National in the endowment of the Arts, humanities, although who knows, who knows what they have said. We can't give you money for. Who knows? Yet, I think as far as my experience with the national humanities and arts are, I think on the whole they've been marvelous. You know, I I'm privately I'd be willing to sacrifice a little freedom in order to get what has been given as far as the theater is concerned. I have functioned as a as a judge and the first American college original college theater play program. Do you know about that? I do, yeah. It's I've forgotten about four years ago. I think it was three years ago, three of us, uh, the drama critic of the Washington Post, uh, Richard Dick Coe and I and and, uh, Vera Roberts of, um, Columbia, I think, or NYU, who was in the Department of Drama department there consisted of, uh, we were the three judges in the first annual Playwrights Award. College playwrights. Uh, and we saw marvelous programs, extraordinarily good plays. And that is the play we selected to win. And the second one was all very good. Uh, they're having a devil of a time getting support for that each year. They've been they've been gotten they've gotten support from industry from from Standard Oil or United Airlines or something like that. But they cannot manage to get sufficient support to make that So they sort of hang by their fingernails. Now that's, I think, is a practical answer to your question as to whether there's a chance of a national setup. Of course, there are dangers getting money from oil companies or from IBM also in terms of freedom of expression too, isn't it? Well, do you see this as. No, I don't see that. Yeah. Because they don't dare. You see, they don't dare. Today we have the most unique situation, I think, in the national history. That is, if I could go to Mobil Oil. And I don't mean literally me, but someone could go. Some scholar can go and say, I want to do a study of oil, the impact of oil on the American life. And I can't guarantee what I will say. I'll bet he would get a subsidy. You know, I think there is there is a kind of enlightenment among industrial leaders today that comes out of self-preservation. I think they feel that if they don't do something, they're going to be nationalized. And this is the last fight against nationalization. Is there anything that I haven't asked you about, the Federal Reserve that should anything that you would like to say in closing, I know you've had a very distinguished career, and that was just one small segment of that career. I don't really, uh, it was just a a good opportunity to see play on to know that you had an audience, but something to know that it would have a run. Uh, in this case, it had there were three, as I remember, three places that it played in Chicago and in and in San Francisco. Um. Its financial support was very. I've forgotten what we got 12, $25 a week or something like that, which Mike gold got 12.5 or something. And they didn't live lavishly. So, uh, but what I think essentially my, uh, feeling about the Federals at a time, it was a time feeling it had nothing to do with my play or any specific play. What it had to do was that there was a kind of excitement. There were people working. There were people creating. There were people giving, given opportunities. There were. There were people willing to risk. Uh, I used to hear from my friend Walter about the bureaucracy in the Federal theater. There was probably a lot of that, too. But despite bureaucracy, which I'm afraid is an inherent part of the human human history. Uh. it was a it was a lively, promising time. And in all the arts and even even outside the even outside the federal theater and the federal arts program. As a as you may know, I'm also a novelist. And I remember those days because one could publish a novel that that the publisher might doubt had commercial possibilities, that more books were published in those years because of the quality of the literary quality, rather than because they thought they could sell them for paperback and movies and television and all that. It was a pure time, as tough as life was because of the economic disruptions. It was a pure time, and everyone looks back on his youth as kind of pure. But I'm not one of those. I think, uh, purity has anything to do with with the time in which one lives. But in terms of the arts, that was a that was a time of great honesty and fever and bubble and creativity and American life. And shall we say, anything in closing about Walter Hartz, would you like to put. Anything. On tape about Walter? Well, I would, I would what an opportunity that is. I would love to. Well, Walter and I have known each other, had known each other since 1925. We met at Penn. Uh, he was a little older, I think, by about a year, but much older by way of his interest in literature and one of the and one of the grandest gifts I ever got in my life, I got from Walter Hart, probably in the in 27 or something. It was a birthday gift to me, and it was a collected, The addition of John Keats, and he wrote in the in the front of the book. My favorite poet to my favorite friend. And, uh, he was a poet. I don't know how many people know that Walter Walter Hart was a poet. I have, I have maybe even here, uh, dozens of his poems. Um, one of the few people I've known in my lifetime who wrote letters in the classical tradition. First place, he didn't type them. He he wrote them longhand and very carefully. And they were rather literary than just informative. Uh, a man who had a fantastic laugh at a party. In a party in the 30s. I used to do this. Then I'd do it occasionally. Now I write a little poems for all the friends who came to the party. Epitaphs. In this case, I wrote epitaph for Walter. And I can't recall it, except that the last line was. Uh, this is. This is for Walter. His epitaph. Um, he may be forgotten for everything, but he'll be remembered for his laugh. Something like that. His laugh was, uh, was, uh, outrageous. And and it was very contagious as well. A handsome man, very talented actor and director. Uh. And in many ways also a cautious man. And if he did not end his life as one of the great directors Of. Of the theatre or film of our time was because he, at decisive moments in his life, was too cautious to make a risky decision. But his talent was first rate. He'd had some success, considerable success on Broadway. But as a human being we we cared a lot for each other. I learned much about books and poetry and theater from Walter, and what pleases me now that he's gone is that his sons and his widow are still alive. His widow is still alive. His sons are. Carry on. Uh, one is a doctor and one is a public defender who was for many years a public defender in Hawaii. Uh, both of them strong, both of them loving, and both of them friends of mine. And that's, um, that's a very satisfying thing to know for me. And I guess if one ever saw the exchange of letters between me and Walter over the years, you'd think we were lovers while we were, in a way. Except not in the not in the way that's understood today. Um, the extremely attractive man, physically. Uh, I think there must have been hundreds of women who were passionately in love with him. Uh, beautiful voice. Poetic. Uh, what more does a woman want? Did you have Walter in mind when you, uh, wrote I met a man in part at least. Or. Uh, I don't remember. I don't remember that I did, um. I certainly wasn't very beautiful friendship between the two men in that novel. The sense of. Yeah, I don't know that I had him in mind, but that is a theme that runs through others of my other books of mine. Um, I really don't. I don't remember that I had him in mind in those days. My notion of, of writing novels is that you write them without living models. I thought if you if if anybody would recognize anybody in the novel, I think I'd failed. Now, I don't believe that anymore. I think living models are a good idea. I'm glad you gave me the opportunity of talking about Wall-E, because I miss him, and and, uh, I I'm glad to hear that. As you said before, that so many people you've interviewed have spoken so well of him. Thank you. Thanks for.

lines.line: > The speaker discusses his pathway to joining the Federal Theatre, which began with his interest in playwriting and his collaboration with Mike Gold on a play about John Brown. Despite initial rejections from other theatres, the Federal Theatre decided to produce their play. The speaker reflects on the minimal involvement he had with the Federal Theatre beyond this play, highlighting a specific instance of creative differences during the production.

metadata.title: Joining the Federal Theatre
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses his pathway to joining the Federal Theatre, which began with his interest in playwriting and his collaboration with Mike Gold on a play about John Brown. Despite initial rejections from other theatres, the Federal Theatre decided to produce their play. The speaker reflects on the minimal involvement he had with the Federal Theatre beyond this play, highlighting a specific instance of creative differences during the production.

lines.line: > The speaker reflects on the broader cultural and artistic impact of the Federal Theatre, discussing its role in supporting artists during the Great Depression and its contributions to American culture. Despite bureaucratic challenges, the speaker recalls a vibrant period of creativity and experimentation facilitated by the Federal Theatre, which supported various artists and allowed them to explore new artistic directions.

metadata.title: Reflections on Federal Theatre's Influence
metadata.synopsis: The speaker reflects on the broader cultural and artistic impact of the Federal Theatre, discussing its role in supporting artists during the Great Depression and its contributions to American culture. Despite bureaucratic challenges, the speaker recalls a vibrant period of creativity and experimentation facilitated by the Federal Theatre, which supported various artists and allowed them to explore new artistic directions.

lines.line: > The speaker explains why John Brown was a significant figure for drama in the 1930s, emphasizing his revolutionary actions and the political climate of the time. The discussion includes how Brown's actions resonated with the Communist Party's slogans and the broader implications of his historical role. The speaker also touches on the literary and historical exploration of American radicals by contemporary writers, which influenced their portrayal of figures like Brown.

metadata.title: John Brown as Dramatic Subject
metadata.synopsis: The speaker explains why John Brown was a significant figure for drama in the 1930s, emphasizing his revolutionary actions and the political climate of the time. The discussion includes how Brown's actions resonated with the Communist Party's slogans and the broader implications of his historical role. The speaker also touches on the literary and historical exploration of American radicals by contemporary writers, which influenced their portrayal of figures like Brown.

lines.line: > The speaker offers a critical view of the Federal Theatre's legacy, suggesting that its primary role was to support artists financially during a difficult period rather than significantly influencing the direction of American theater. He acknowledges the stylistic contributions of the Living Newspaper and the potential influence on children's theater but maintains that the most significant impact was on individual artists rather than the cultural landscape at large.

metadata.title: Legacy of the Federal Theatre
metadata.synopsis: The speaker offers a critical view of the Federal Theatre's legacy, suggesting that its primary role was to support artists financially during a difficult period rather than significantly influencing the direction of American theater. He acknowledges the stylistic contributions of the Living Newspaper and the potential influence on children's theater but maintains that the most significant impact was on individual artists rather than the cultural landscape at large.

lines.line: > The speaker shares heartfelt memories of Walter Hartz, emphasizing their deep friendship and Hartz's influence on his life. He describes Hartz's talents, personality, and the impact he had on others, both personally and professionally. The speaker's anecdotes convey a sense of loss and appreciation for the enduring impact Hartz had on his life and the lives of others.

metadata.title: Personal Reflections on Walter Hartz
metadata.synopsis: The speaker shares heartfelt memories of Walter Hartz, emphasizing their deep friendship and Hartz's influence on his life. He describes Hartz's talents, personality, and the impact he had on others, both personally and professionally. The speaker's anecdotes convey a sense of loss and appreciation for the enduring impact Hartz had on his life and the lives of others.

children.text: > The speaker discusses his pathway to joining the Federal Theatre, which began with his interest in playwriting and his collaboration with Mike Gold on a play about John Brown. Despite initial rejections from other theatres, the Federal Theatre decided to produce their play. The speaker reflects on the minimal involvement he had with the Federal Theatre beyond this play, highlighting a specific instance of creative differences during the production.

> The speaker reflects on the broader cultural and artistic impact of the Federal Theatre, discussing its role in supporting artists during the Great Depression and its contributions to American culture. Despite bureaucratic challenges, the speaker recalls a vibrant period of creativity and experimentation facilitated by the Federal Theatre, which supported various artists and allowed them to explore new artistic directions.

> The speaker explains why John Brown was a significant figure for drama in the 1930s, emphasizing his revolutionary actions and the political climate of the time. The discussion includes how Brown's actions resonated with the Communist Party's slogans and the broader implications of his historical role. The speaker also touches on the literary and historical exploration of American radicals by contemporary writers, which influenced their portrayal of figures like Brown.

> The speaker offers a critical view of the Federal Theatre's legacy, suggesting that its primary role was to support artists financially during a difficult period rather than significantly influencing the direction of American theater. He acknowledges the stylistic contributions of the Living Newspaper and the potential influence on children's theater but maintains that the most significant impact was on individual artists rather than the cultural landscape at large.

> The speaker shares heartfelt memories of Walter Hartz, emphasizing their deep friendship and Hartz's influence on his life. He describes Hartz's talents, personality, and the impact he had on others, both personally and professionally. The speaker's anecdotes convey a sense of loss and appreciation for the enduring impact Hartz had on his life and the lives of others.

story.title: Dr. Michael Blankfort, July 22, 1977
story.description:
